question: Let $p(x)$ be quadratic with rational coefficients.  If $p(\sqrt{7}) = 22$ and $p(\sqrt{11}) = 30,$ then find $p(\sqrt{17}).$
answer:
Let $p(x) = ax^2 + bx + c.$  Then
\begin{align*}
7a + b \sqrt{7} + c &= 22, \\
11a + b \sqrt{11} + c &= 30.
\end{align*}Since $a,$ $b,$ and $c$ are rational, the only way that the equations above can hold is if $b = 0.$  Then
\begin{align*}
7a + c &= 22, \\
11a + c &= 30.
\end{align*}Solving this system, we find $a = 2$ and $c = 8.$

Then $p(x) = 2x^2 + 8,$ so $p(\sqrt{17}) = 2 \cdot 17 + 8 = \boxed{42}.$
agents_response:
Let $p(x) = ax^2 + bx + c.$ Since $p(x)$ has rational coefficients, $\sqrt{7}$ and $\sqrt{11}$ must be roots of $p(x).$ Therefore, we have that
\begin{align*}
p(x) &= a(x - \sqrt{7})(x - \sqrt{11}) \\
&= a(x^2 - (\sqrt{11} + \sqrt{7})x + \sqrt{77}).
\end{align*}Plugging in $p(\sqrt{7}) = 22$ and $p(\sqrt{11}) = 30,$ we get
\begin{align*}
a(\sqrt{77}) &= 22 \quad \text{and} \\
a( - 2\sqrt{11} ) &= 30.
\end{align*}It follows that $a = \frac{22}{\sqrt{77}} = \frac{22\sqrt{77}}{77} = \frac{22}{7} \sqrt{77},$ so \[p(x) = \frac{22}{7} \sqrt{77} \left( x^2 - (\sqrt{11} + \sqrt{7})x + \sqrt{77} \right).\]Plugging in $x = \sqrt{17}$ gives $p(\sqrt{17}) = \frac{22}{7} \sqrt{77} \left( 17 - \sqrt{28} - \sqrt{7} \right) = \frac{22}{7} \sqrt{77} \left( 9 - \sqrt{7} \right) = \boxed{198}.$
